messageBody:
I have had to do similar things. The solution I came up with was to
make an abstract base class that extends TestCase. All this class does
is implement the setup and teardown methods. Then I extend it with
classes that have the test methods. So with your example:



abstract class AbstractBase extends TestCase {



public void setUp() {

// do common setup here.

}



public void tearDown(){

// do common clean up here

}

}



class A extends AbstractBase {

public testA(){}

}



class B extends AbstractBase {

public testB(){}

}



I typically don't use the suit or main methods so I don't know if that
will affect this.

Hope this helps

Adam

-----Original Message-----
From: Alok Daipuria [mailto:alok.daipuria@...]
Sent: Tuesday, February 25, 2003 10:43 AM
To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
Subject: [junit] suppressing test cases from base class in an
extended class


I have an existing test case class which I extended to add few
more test
cases. When I run the extended test case, it runs the test cases
from the
base class as well. Is there a flag or something which I can use
to suppress
running test cases present in the base class.
Here's an example of the scenario :

class A extends TestCase
{
public testA() {}
}

class B extends A
{
public testB() {}
}

When I execute class B, it runs both testA() and testB(),
which I want to
avoid for now. I need to extend to be able to use the
setup/teardown done by
A.

-alok
